awd_titl_txt: Living Fossils: Integrating Phylogenomics and Comparative Morphology to Assemble the Scorpion Tree of Life
awd_abstract_narration:
Scorpions are dominant arthropod predators in most terrestrial habitats on all major landmasses except Antarctica, and their anatomy has changed very little in the past 435 million years. Every year, 1.2 million scorpion stings cause 3,250 human fatalities worldwide. Scorpion venoms, cocktails of neurotoxins that block nerve impulses, offer great potential for medicine, including treatment of brain cancer and autoimmune diseases, non-addictive painkillers, and ecofriendly insecticides. Despite the antiquity, notoriety, global distribution, ecological, and medical importance of these "living fossils", scorpion classification is contentious and the scorpion tree of life ambiguously resolved, hindering the testing of important hypotheses concerning scorpion evolution, and exploration of the pharmacological potential of scorpion venom. By integrating genomic and morphological data from living and fossil scorpions, this project will provide the most comprehensive analysis of the scorpion tree of life and the evolutionary position of scorpions, to date. The project will support a Ph.D. student and three postdoctoral associates, all from underrepresented groups. Each year, an undergraduate, two high school students, and two citizen scientists will be involved in research. Courses on scorpion biology, classification, and medical importance, with an introduction to the local fauna, will be presented on four continents. New material, data, and images will enhance scientific infrastructure. Results, data, and educational outreach materials will be disseminated online and via nationally distributed classroom magazines.

The project has several primary aims. First, using a high-throughput, targeted enrichment approach, approximately 300,000 bases of DNA sequence, per specimen, will be generated for representatives of all major lineages, at least 80% of the genera of living scorpions, and all living orders of Chelicerata. A matrix of morphological observations will be completed for all species in the genomic dataset and representatives of extinct lineages of scorpions and their chelicerate relatives. Additionally, the phylogeny and morphology will be used to present a predictive classification of scorpions above the level of genus and investigate questions concerning the evolution and diversification of scorpions and their venoms. The project will include extensive fieldwork and collaboration with international colleagues and will represent the most comprehensive evolutionary study of any chelicerate group. A greater understanding of how venom has evolved across the scorpion tree of life will provide the necessary data to fine-tune the use of venom in medicine.

por.por_cntn:
Scorpions are dominant invertebrate predators in most terrestrial habitats and elevations on all major landmasses except Antarctica, and have changed little morphologically in 435 million years. Scorpions are notorious in places like Mexico, where 100,000 envenomations (out of 1.2 million globally) cause up to 800 fatalities (out of 3,250 globally) every year. Scorpion venoms, cocktails of neurotoxins that prevent transmission of nerve impulses, offer tremendous potential for medicine, including treatment of cancerous brain gliomas and autoimmune diseases, nonaddictive painkillers and ecofriendly insecticides.

Despite the antiquity, notoriety, global distribution, ecological and medical importance of these ’living fossils’, progress in scorpion systematics and evolutionary biology lags behind other comparable arthropod groups, hindering their classification, the testing of hypotheses concerning their evolution and diversification, and exploration of the pharmacological potential of their venom. The project aimed to (1) apply a high-throughput, targeted enrichment approach to develop a comprehensive genomic dataset for representatives of all major lineages of living scorpions and other orders of Chelicerata; (2) develop a matrix of morphological observations to complement the genomic dataset; (3) use the phylogeny and morphology to present a predictive classification of scorpions; and (4) to investigate questions concerning scorpion evolution and diversification. In achieving these objectives, the project vastly improved the level of knowledge, infrastructure and public interest in these notorious arachnids.

Intellectual Merit: Field inventories were fundamental to the project aims, allowing participants to gather fresh material for comparative genomics and morphology; discover new taxa and distribution records; improve the understanding of known taxa; strengthen international collaborative networks; and train postdoctoral associates and students from high school to graduate level. Sixty-four field expeditions, fully or partly supported by the project, and another 20 excursions, funded by other sources, were conducted in 46 countries on five continents. Ten natural history collections in Belgium, France, the Netherlands, South Africa, Thailand, the U.K., and the U.S. were visited to examine and image type and non-type material and to score morphological characters. External morphology and internal anatomy of the major groups of scorpions were investigated and documented using field-collected and museum material. Two probe kits for targeted enrichment were developed, allowing the capture of at least 300 loci from a comprehensive sample of extant scorpions and chelicerate outgroups. Nineteen new genomes of scorpions and other arachnids were also sequenced. The evolutionary tree assisted the revision of scorpion higher classification and the understanding of scorpion evolution and diversification. Several scorpion families and genera were revised, including descriptions of new genera and species, using freshly collected and museum material, modern concepts and methods. Scorpion evolution and diversification was illuminated through biogeographical reconstructions and molecular divergence dating. Many new scorpions and other arachnids, as well as many new records and range-extensions, were discovered during grant-funded fieldwork. Major studies on the systematics of other arachnid orders, including descriptions of new taxa, were also published as an outcome of grant-funded research.

Broader Impacts: The project developed human resources and enhanced diversity in STEM. Thirty-one trainees were involved in project research, 70% from underrepresented groups: four postdoctoral associates; four graduate students (one Ph.D., three M.S.); 14 undergraduate students, two via an NSF REU site grant and eight via a collaborative program with Rutgers University; 19 high school students via the AMNH Science Research Mentoring Program, AMNH Lang Science Program, and AMNH Volunteer Program; one volunteer. Training involved field techniques (e.g., specimen collection, preservation, ethics and legal issues), taxonomic practices (e.g., identification, curatorial techniques, production of illustrations, collection of morphometric and meristic data), and/or laboratory skills (e.g., genomic DNA extraction and quantitation, microscopy, digital imaging). Senior personnel participated in expeditions with postdoctoral associates and students to provide training and intellectual interactions in the field setting. Many trainees contributed to publications. Scientific infrastructure was enhanced by the collection of new specimens and tissues; synthesis of data in existing collections through sorting, identification and databasing unsorted and unidentified material; production of high-resolution digital images of specimens and morphological characters; development of probe kits for targeted enrichment of chelicerates; and production of whole genomes, DNA sequences and a morphological character matrix for scorpions and chelicerates. Project activities, personnel, results and publications were uploaded to the website of the Scorpion Systematics Research Group, Arachnology @ AMNH (https://scorpion.amnh.org), which provides a range of information and resources about scorpions and other arachnids, relevant to a broad user community. Research findings were disseminated via open-access scientific publications, popular science publications, presentations at national and international meetings, public lectures, tours and demonstrations, and outreach contributions to websites, blogs, newsletters and citizen science databases.
